sentence: It was shaping up to be a decent downside day, but as the afternoon progressed investors were able to shake off the saving daylight fatigue to lift the indices to finish in positive territory.
Gold-mining plays like Newmont Mining ( NEM ) and Goldcorp ( GG ) saw a good chunk of buying interest as the yellow metal crept up near the $1800 an ounce level.
There wasn't much to report on the earnings side, with Sysco Foods ( SYY ) being the sole headline name out with a report this morning .
SYY shares closed fairly unchanged on the day.
The lift in oil prices today helped boost shares of major oil integrated plays such as Chevron ( CVX ), Exxon Mobil ( XOM ), and ConocoPhillips ( COP ).
A couple of well-known brands got some Wall Street analyst love this morning.
Shares of Home Depot ( HD ) gained nicely on the day, while shares of Nike ( NKE ) failed to hold the early pop and closed down on the day.
You can view the commentary for Home Depot here , and for Nike here .
The New York Times had an interesting article recently about Time Warner ( TWX ) and the media giant's potential strategy to streamline its operations.
This plan could include consolidating most of its four million square feet of office space.
The company is estimating it could save up to $150 million a year with such a move.
As corporate America continues to come under scrutiny, especially with the poor job market and lack of hiring, many companies could may forgo lavish office complexes for more practical spaces.
This development would spell trouble for Commercial REITs (Real Estate Investment Trusts), such as Vornado Property Group ( VNO ) and Boston Properties ( BXP ).
Both names are currently sporting less-than-attractive dividend yields (BXP for example is yielding barely over 2%).
As I have mentioned before, REITs have been a bit of a conundrum for dividend investors.
The sector's overall subpar yields and lack of significant pullbacks (from a price standpoint) simply don't make the stocks very attractive.
Momentum fund managers, on the other hand, tend not to care about yield as much as they do stocks that have been outperforming.
An opportunity to get into some of the high-profile commercial REITs could be coming at some point, but for now, we remain on the sidelines waiting for better entry points.

Only Make Big Moves if You've Got a Lot to Gain

I was watching an older episode of "Mad Men" on AMC (great show if you have a chance to check it out), where a couple of the characters were being offered jobs at a competing ad agency.
The offer was, in essence, just a lateral move for the characters.
They weren't being offered much more money, and the details of their new roles were still being hammered out.
But of course, the mere thought of making such a big move caused plenty of stress.
This plot development got me thinking about the times we're faced with similar decisions in our own lives.
Sometimes we'll be greeted with an opportunity to see what's behind a new door in our careers.
But many times, the results of these moves aren't as great as had been originally expected.
The grass is always greener on the other side, as they say.
Moving from one home to another can also end with similar results.
I remember when I was about 10 years old, my father came home one day and told my mother about an apartment that was opening up in his friend's building not too far away.
He thought it would be a good idea for us to move there, since the place was a little bit bigger and his friend owned the building.
My mom promptly put her foot down, however, and said if we ever move, it'll be to our own detached house and not just another apartment.
To her, the hassle of packing and moving up the street to end up in another apartment made no sense.
My dad realized she was right.
Just one year later, we ended moving into our own house after an opportunity came up across town near my dad's barbershop.
It was well worth the wait, and I credit my mom for realizing that if you're going to make a move, it better be a significant upgrade.
Otherwise, the stress and hassle probably isn't worth it.
Is there a direct connection to investing to be gleaned from this concept?
Maybe not.
But your when your overall financial health suffers, so does your investing.
Trade your reliable car in for a new one with a high monthly payment, and you'll likely have less money each month to invest.
Move into an apartment much bigger than you really need and your monthly expenses increase significantly, again taking a big chunk away from your investing potential.
Is leaving your company and losing your seniority for a few extra dollars really worth it?
After all, you may be able to talk your current employer into giving you a pay raise.
You'd be amazed how many people will just blindside their company with a notice they're leaving, without speaking with them first.
They may have missed out on a tremendous opportunity for a pay raise or advancement as a result.
So, be sure to think any big potential changes in your life through.
Never make a change just for the sake of change.
If the move isn't a clear upgrade, then wait for a better opportunity.
You'll be glad you did.
